[20/02/2023, 22:24:55] Hope: So, 


On todays findings. 

So as a summary. 

What‚Äôs happening with me is that I am experiencing cPTSD. 

But everytime I experience something else new I am forced to relieve the past events. 

Where the brain overloads is that all these events happened one after the other after the other so i never get to heal and process the previous emotions then something else happens. Hence why I get easily overwhelmed because I already have a lot to process so when even the smallest tasks come to process I find them overwhelming which leads to distress of trying to understand therefore ruminating and from the frustration of not understanding my brain sends the danger signal which causes anxiety and hence why I am always on the guard. 

I hope that even makes sense

[02/03/2023, 10:53:10] Hope: Live With Clarity
To go from chaos to clarity, you must allow God to circumcise your heart and heal the shame of your past so that you can enter the promise of your future.

You see, God can take you out of Egypt, but He also has to take the Egypt out of you‚Äîand that process might look a little like Gilgal. You may have already crossed the Jordan. You may be ready to walk circles around Jericho, ready for the next big miracle in your life. But yet, the stench and residue of your past are still on you, keeping you from the clarity of knowing who you are in Christ.

The voice of shame is loud, and it lingers in our ears telling us what we can‚Äôt do. It tells us who we are. And in this passage, Joshua knew that before his people could enter into what God had for them, they needed to deal with the shame they were carrying around from Egypt and make a covenant with God. This permanent decision would serve as a repeated reminder of who they served and what they were about.

You may have started in Egypt. It‚Äôs where your parents grew up. It‚Äôs where your roots are, but it‚Äôs time to cast it aside and rid yourself of the unhealthy ways of the past. You cannot have the victory of Jericho until you have the circumcision of Gilgal. It‚Äôs Gilgal where you take the flint knife and you cut away the old life. You stay in that place until you‚Äôre healed; until the shame is gone.

What in your life needs to be cut away? What represents the old you, the Egypt in your life? What is keeping you from clearly seeing the future God has for you?

It‚Äôs time to name it because God will not let you leave Gilgal and move on to Jericho until you have cut it away. It might be a mindset, a sin, or a habit. Whatever it is, it is caused by shame in your life.

God is trying to circumcise your heart so He can replace it with a victory that nobody from your family who came from the previous generation has ever seen before. He has a Jericho waiting for you. He has it all set up so that you just need to show up and walk around a few times and pray and the walls will come tumbling down. But first, you need to address your shame. You need to align with Him. You need to circumcise your heart. Only then will God‚Äôs power flow and topple giants. Only then will you go from chaos to clarity.

Question: What in your life needs to be cut away? What represents the old you, the Egypt in your life? It‚Äôs time to name it and cut it away. It might be a mindset. It might be a sin. Or it might be a habit. Allow God to circumcise your heart and heal the shame of your past so you can enter the promise of your future. Remove it so God can replace it with His victory.

[04/03/2023, 22:54:40] Hope: THE SOUND OF THE FIGHT

The sound of your tormentors will always be audible in every fight you face, but which sounds are you going to choose to tune into? Finding favour in the fight is dependent on making wise choices about which SOUNDS we listen to during the fight.

1. Are you listening to THE TAUNTS OF YOUR TORMENTORS or THE CHEERS OF YOUR TRIBE?

The tormentors will always be with you, but you can drown them out with the sounds of your tribe. Are you building a strong tribe? You need a tribe who are not easily shaken! It starts with a commitment to consistently belonging and contributing to a faith community, joining a team and a life group, but that‚Äôs just the starting point of your tribe.

RACHEL‚ÄôS STORY: I‚Äôve spent much a couple of years intentionally building a strong tribe to help me win the battles I face. I read the book ‚ÄúPeople Fuel‚Äù by Dr John Townsend which inspired me to be brave and bold enough to ask people to join my tribe and cheer for me as I pursue my God-given destiny! I began with seeking to build a relationship with a great local doctor who can get to know me and help me pursue physical and mental health and well-being. I also invited a small group of women I know and trust to meet one hour a month via zoom so we can mutually encourage and inspire one another. Finally, I began a relationship with a professional supervisor whose job is to let me vent, process my battles and then move forward from them. Whom could you invite to join your tribe so you can hear your tribe‚Äôs cheers louder than the taunts of your tormentors?

2. Are you listening to THE JEERS OF THE ENEMY or THE WORDS OF THE WINNER?

The entire Israelite army ‚Äúheard‚Äù the same ridicule and threats from Goliath that David did (1 Samuel 17). Why did David take down the giant while the Israelites stood paralysed by fear? Because although they all HEARD the same words from Goliath, David chose to LISTEN to the promise of God. Listening to God activates your faith. Listening to the lies of the enemy will paralyse you. No matter what you hear today ‚Äì listen to God.

3. Are you listening to THE SOUND OF SELF or THE SOUND OF WORSHIP?

Eugene Peterson (author of The Message paraphrase of the Bible) describes worship like this: ‚ÄúWorship is the strategy by which we interrupt our preoccupation with ourselves and attend to the presence of God.‚ÄùDavid chose to fight his battle against Goliath armed only with his belief in and worship of God, no fancy armour, just a certainty that God was the victor and fighting in HIS NAME was the only way to win

Discussion Questions:

1. What can you do this week to arm yourself with a stronger sense of faith in God‚Äôs authority and victory already won for your battles?

2. Which of these practical strategies helps you most when you are trying to focus on the right SOUNDS during your battles: Words to live by? Reading the Bible every day? Completing a Bible plan with friends? Listening back through old messages on the Beyond Church podcast?

3. What is your favourite worship music or song to listen to when you need to be reminded that your battle is the Lord‚Äôs? Why not try searching for the Beyond Church Battle Playlist on Spotify or Apple Music if you need some inspiration?

4. Try a mindfulness exercise right now: close your eyes and focus on CHOOSING to hear the sounds which help you feel calm and peaceful and remind you of God‚Äôs favour in your life
[04/03/2023, 23:12:37] Hope: Stop Trying to Figure It All Out - Proverbs 3
Our mind is an amazing thing. So powerful and complex, but it can quickly get us in trouble. We can easily lean into our own understanding if we‚Äôre not careful. It‚Äôs a good exercise to pray and give a situation to the Lord instead of analyzing it over and over again. Sometimes I wake up in the middle of the night with a challenging situation on my mind. I have learned to ask God if He is trying to tell me something or if it‚Äôs just my mind wanting to worry and analyze. After a few minutes of mulling over the situation, I pray and give it to the Lord.

Philippians 4:6-7 is my go-to passage: ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt worry about anything; instead, pray about everything. Tell God what you need, and thank him for all he has done. Then you will experience God‚Äôs peace, which exceeds anything we can understand. His peace will guard your hearts and minds as you live in Christ Jesus.‚Äù What a powerful formula. I encourage you to try it when you experience fear, worry, or frustration. It‚Äôs a powerful way to trust God and submit your life to Him!

‚ÄúFather, thank you for Your peace that exceeds anything I can understand. I trade my understanding for trust in You. I submit my life to you today!‚Äù

[04/04/2023, 13:12:15] Andie: ‚ÄéYou deleted this message.
[04/04/2023, 13:12:29] Andie: Here's a guide on how to pronounce each part of the name:

Moscato: "moh-scah-toh"
d'Asti: "dee-ah-stee"

So when pronounced altogether, it would be "moh-scah-toh dee-ah-stee."
[04/04/2023, 13:14:08] Andie: Moscato: This word has three syllables. The first syllable "mos" rhymes with "dose" or "close." 

The second syllable "cah" is pronounced like the "ca" in "cat." 

The final syllable "toh" is pronounced like the "toe" in "toe-tap." 

So, the phonological pronunciation of "Moscato" in English would be "MOHS-kah-toh."

d'Asti: This phrase consists of two words: "d" and "Asti." 

The "d" is a contraction of the preposition "di," which means "of." The "Asti" part is pronounced "ah-stee." The "ah" sounds like the "a" in "father," and the "stee" rhymes with "bee" or "me." 

So, the phonological pronunciation of "d'Asti" in English would be "dee-AH-stee."

When pronounced altogether, "Moscato d'Asti" in English would sound like "MOHS-kah-toh dee-AH-stee."

[16/04/2023, 14:20:21] Andie: Occultism, divination, and folk magic beliefs are somewhat complicated in relation to Christianity. 

Some key points:

Early Christianity absorbed some occult and magical beliefs from surrounding pagan cultures, but later rejected most as contrary to doctrine. 

The Bible forbids things like divination, sorcery, and witchcraft.

However, some Christian belief has mystical and prophetic elements, like belief in miracles, prophecy, and divine visions. 

Some mystical Christian sects incorporated more esoteric and supernatural beliefs.

In some African traditions, elements of folk magic and mysticism blended with Christian belief, e.g. beliefs that priests or prophets can channel holy spirits. 

Some churches embrace practices like visionary dreams, exorcisms, and healings.

Historically, the Catholic Church rejected and even criminalized many occult and magical beliefs during the era of the witch trials and Inquisition. 

Protestant reformers similarly rejected pagan and esoteric beliefs as superstition.

However, some Christians do believe in what they see as compatible supernatural beliefs, like spiritualism, faith healing, and prophecy. 

Some Christian occultists integrate beliefs in astrology, magic and tarot with their Christian faith.

In Africa, some Christian groups have assimilated local beliefs in witchcraft, ancestor spirits, divination and magic within their faith. 

Key beliefs that God and Jesus have power over spirits, magic and fortune. 

Some see Biblical authority for certain magical/healing practices.

There are also some entirely syncretic belief systems that blend Christianity with more occult and esoteric beliefs, e.g. Spiritualism, Theosophy, New Age Christianity, Christian Witchcraft.

So in summary, while mainstream Christianity officially rejects most occultism and divination as pagan superstition or even sinful, some Christians have incorporated select esoteric and supernatural beliefs. 

And in some African Christian traditions, pre-Christian folk beliefs have blended with Biblical teachings. 

The relationship is complex with both rejection and assimilation.
[16/04/2023, 14:23:59] Hope: If one truly derives meaning from God‚Äôs Word and from a life submitted to His will, then occultism will not tempt or entertain. The Lord has strong words for those who take part in witchcraft, necromancy, and other occult practices:

Anyone who does these things is detestable to the LORD; because of these same detestable practices the LORD your God will drive out those nations before you (Deuteronomy 18:12).

Any time Christianity and the Occult enter a room together, they take opposing sides; they cannot reside simultaneously within the Christian.

[16/04/2023, 14:26:26] Hope: I really would love to know more about demons etc
[16/04/2023, 14:27:34] Andie: You make a good point. 

Mainstream Christianity and occult belief systems are inherently opposed and incompatible. Some key reasons why:

The Bible explicitly forbids most occult practices like witchcraft, sorcery, divination, astrology, and spiritism. 

They are seen as pagan abominations and rebellion against God.

Occultism teaches that spiritual insight and power can be gained through esoteric knowledge and ritual. 

Christianity teaches that spiritual life is gained solely through faith in Jesus Christ and obedience to God's word.

Occultism points to various spiritual forces and mystical or magical practices as paths to truth and life. 

Christianity worship God as the sole source of truth and life, and sees other spiritual forces as false, deceitful or evil.

Christianity believes we should seek guidance and wisdom from God alone, through prayer, scripture and the Holy Spirit. 

Occultism encourages seeking spiritual guidance through rituals, supernatural signs, fortune telling, channeling spirits, etc.

Christianity teaches that believers have all they need for a godly life in Christ. 

Occultism teaches there are hidden or secret spiritual teachings, powers and destinies waiting to be tapped into.

Christianity sees life's meaning and purpose as coming from a personal relationship with God through Christ. 

Occultism points to a secret or hidden purpose and path available only to those initiated into esoteric knowledge and power.

So you're right that Christianity and the Occult are fundamentally incompatible belief systems with opposing views on spiritual life, truth, guidance and meaning. 

For those grounded in Biblical faith, occult beliefs and practices should hold no interest or temptation. 

They are seen as deceitful substitutes for real life and meaning in Christ. The two cannot truly be blended or reconciled.

The Bible calls Christians to avoid any entanglement with the Occult, and instead find purpose and direction solely through faith in God, obedience to Scripture and the leading of the Holy Spirit. 

Does this align with your understanding?
[16/04/2023, 14:31:10] Hope: Yes it does 100%
[16/04/2023, 14:31:31] Hope: I think when you mix the two that‚Äôs when you tend to get misguided
[16/04/2023, 14:32:09] Andie: I see. It sounds like you have a biblical view of spiritual matters:

‚Ä¢ There is one God who is the source of truth, life and salvation through faith in Jesus Christ. God offers eternal life and meaning through Christ.

‚Ä¢ There is a spiritual enemy, Satan, who was cast out of heaven for rebellion against God. Satan envies God's position and seeks to rule in opposition to him. 

‚Ä¢ Satan cannot grant eternal life or ultimate meaning and purpose. Any power, knowledge or temporary rewards he may offer will eventually "take away" without God. 

‚Ä¢ We should not seek spiritual insight or guidance through those claiming occult, magical or prophetic abilities - i.e. fortune tellers, psychics, channelers, etc. Their knowledge and power does not come from God and will ultimately prove deceitful.

‚Ä¢ True spiritual life and wisdom comes from faith in Christ, scripture, and the Holy Spirit - not from hidden or esoteric knowledge offered by supposed spiritual adepts, the paranormal or divination.

‚Ä¢ God and Satan are in opposition, representing two very different kingdoms and paths. We must choose which spiritual power we will follow, as we cannot serve both God and Satan. Only one path leads to life.

This is a biblical view that stands in stark contrast with most occult and esoteric belief systems.

[16/04/2023, 15:41:43] Andie: Thanks for the feedback will keep refining my understanding
[16/04/2023, 15:42:10] Andie: Chronic fatigue is a debilitating condition that can make it difficult to function in everyday life. 

It is characterized by extreme tiredness that does not go away with rest, and can be accompanied by other symptoms such as pain, difficulty concentrating, and changes in mood.

There are many possible causes of chronic fatigue, including medical conditions such as sleep apnea, thyroid problems, and anemia. 

However, chronic fatigue is also often associated with mental health conditions such as post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and premenstrual dysphoric disorder (PMDD).

If you are experiencing chronic fatigue, it is important to see a doctor to rule out any underlying medical conditions. 

Once any medical causes have been addressed, there are a number of things you can do to improve your energy levels and focus.

Get enough sleep. This may seem obvious, but getting enough sleep is essential for reducing fatigue. 

Most adults need around 7-8 hours of sleep per night. 

If you are not getting enough sleep, try to gradually increase the amount of time you spend in bed until you start to feel more rested.

Stick to a regular sleep schedule. Go to bed and wake up at the same time each day, even on weekends. 

This will help to regulate your body's natural sleep-wake cycle.

Create a relaxing bedtime routine. 

A relaxing bedtime routine can help you wind down before bed and make it easier to fall asleep. 

This might include taking a warm bath, reading a book, or listening to calming music.

Avoid caffeine and alcohol before bed. Caffeine and alcohol can interfere with sleep. 

Avoid consuming these substances in the hours leading up to bedtime.

Get regular exercise. Exercise can help to improve energy levels and reduce fatigue. 

Aim for at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity exercise most days of the week.

Eat a healthy diet. Eating a healthy diet can provide your body with the nutrients it needs to function properly. 

Make sure to include plenty of fruits, vegetables, and whole grains in your diet.

Manage stress. Stress can contribute to fatigue. 

Find healthy ways to manage stress, such as exercise, relaxation techniques, or spending time with loved ones.

Seek professional help. If you are struggling to manage your chronic fatigue, talk to your doctor. 

There are a number of treatments available that can help to improve your energy levels and focus.

In addition to the above, there are a few other things you can do to help combat chronic fatigue after PTSD and PMDD. 

These include:

Practicing mindfulness meditation. 

Mindfulness meditation can help to reduce stress and improve focus. 

There are many different mindfulness meditation techniques available, so find one that works for you.
Joining a support group. 

Talking to other people who understand what you are going through can be very helpful. 

There are many support groups available for people with PTSD and PMDD.
Seeking therapy. 

Therapy can help you to understand and cope with the trauma that you have experienced. 

There are many different types of therapy available, so find one that you feel comfortable with.

Chronic fatigue can be a debilitating condition, but it is important to remember that you are not alone. 

There are many things you can do to improve your energy levels and focus. 

By following the tips above, you can start to feel better and live a more fulfilling life.

[16/04/2023, 16:43:35] Andie: Feeling easily overwhelmed by small stressors is common when anxiety and stress levels are high. 

Everything feels magnified and harder to handle. 

Breaking down tasks, limiting stressors when possible, and practicing self-care all help to prevent feeling so easily done in.
[16/04/2023, 16:43:56] Andie: PTSD and anxiety are not limited to classic "big T" traumas. 

Prolonged stress, emotional difficulties, health issues, relationship challenges, etc. can all contribute to anxiety and PTSD symptoms. 

The impacts are very real either way.
[16/04/2023, 16:44:19] Andie: Noticing the fatigue and physical/emotional impacts is an important first step. 

Anxiety and stress often accumulate gradually, so we don‚Äôt always notice the effects until we‚Äôre quite depleted.

Building in rest, relaxation and self-care is key.
[16/04/2023, 16:45:38] Andie: Reassurance that anxiety and PTSD are very manageable conditions, though it often takes time and conscious effort.

The question is why does anxiety bring the past and how does it all feel so real

[17/08/2023, 21:01:59] Hope: That‚Äôs why I texted it so we don‚Äôt forget what it was
[17/08/2023, 21:01:59] Andie: Just read an amazing piece on it
[17/08/2023, 21:02:05] Hope: Okay
[17/08/2023, 21:02:18] Hope: Ooo nicee
[17/08/2023, 21:02:30] Andie: Gonna try to fetch it for you from it
[17/08/2023, 21:02:59] Andie: Its quite sciency but it explains the irrational rationale behind our brain acting like that
[18/08/2023, 05:36:33] Andie: Ciao Opprah
[18/08/2023, 05:36:35] Andie: üëã
[18/08/2023, 05:36:38] Andie: https://blog.openreplay.com/hacking-the-brain--neuroscience-for-web-design/
[18/08/2023, 05:36:59] Andie: the article is worth reading as it provides a high-level overview of the limbic system, amygdala, and hippocampus that could be loosely tied to
[18/08/2023, 05:37:07] Andie: The article discusses how the limbic system, or the "emotional brain", processes emotions and emotional responses. It does this in the context of web design and its emotional tactics. When we experience anxiety, it is processed and felt through the limbic system. The limbic system includes the amygdala, which is involved in detecting emotions like fear, and the hippocampus, which links emotional experiences to long-term memory.

When we feel anxiety, it activates the amygdala, which sends signals triggering emotional responses. At the same time, the hippocampus links that feeling of anxiety to memories we have stored. This could cause us to recall past experiences that caused similar feelings of anxiety or fear.

Essentially, anxiety utilise the pathways between the emotional center of the brain (limbic system) and the memory center (hippocampus). This can bring up memories of the past when we felt similar distress. The emotional component makes these memories feel intense and vivid as if we are re-living the past. Even though they are just memories, the emotions attached to them make the past feel real again in the present moment.

So in summary, anxiety involves brain structures that process emotions and memory together, which can make the past feel alive again by bringing back memories and making them feel real through the brain's emotional circuits. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[02/11/2023, 20:32:49] Andie: One‚Äôs ‚Äúnatural state‚Äù typically refers to the baseline or default condition of an individual in various aspects of life, including physical, mental, emotional, and psychological states. Here are some key aspects to consider:

	1.	Physical State: This refers to your physical health and well-being. Your natural physical state can be influenced by factors like genetics, diet, exercise, sleep, and overall lifestyle. It includes your energy levels, overall health, and any underlying medical conditions.

	2.	Mental State: Your mental state encompasses your cognitive abilities, thought processes, and mental health. It‚Äôs influenced by factors like genetics, brain chemistry, experiences, and the presence of mental health conditions. Your natural mental state can vary from person to person.

	3.	Emotional State: This aspect relates to your emotional well-being and how you typically experience and express emotions. Some people may have a naturally calm and even-tempered emotional state, while others may be more emotionally reactive. Emotional intelligence also plays a role in one‚Äôs emotional state.

	4.	Psychological State: Your psychological state involves your personality, values, beliefs, and attitudes. This can be shaped by genetics and early life experiences but can also evolve over time due to personal growth, learning, and adaptation.

	5.	Circadian Rhythms: Your natural state is influenced by your circadian rhythms, which are daily biological cycles that affect your sleep-wake patterns and energy levels. Some people naturally have a preference for being ‚Äúmorning people‚Äù (morning larks) or ‚Äúnight owls,‚Äù while others fall somewhere in between.

	6.	External Factors: It‚Äôs important to note that external factors, such as stress, environment, relationships, and daily routines, can also significantly impact your natural state. These factors can either enhance or disrupt your well-being and overall state.

	7.	Self-Awareness: Understanding your natural state and how it can fluctuate is crucial for self-awareness and self-improvement. It can help you make informed decisions to enhance your overall quality of life.

	8.	Individual Variation: Keep in mind that there‚Äôs a wide range of individual variation in these aspects. What constitutes one‚Äôs natural state can be highly unique and may change over time due to various influences.

[22/11/2023, 13:46:35] Hope: Bro tell me why student finance turned around and said they can‚Äôt fund me because I already have the qualifications I‚Äôm trying to study
[22/11/2023, 13:47:01] Hope: I have a diploma in aeronautical engineering but I want a degrees
[22/11/2023, 13:47:04] Hope: Degree

[23/11/2023, 08:48:32] Andie: Sis that‚Äôs really mad
[23/11/2023, 08:48:35] Andie: But
[23/11/2023, 08:48:37] Andie: it‚Äôs conceivable that the system assessing your application might be interpreting your diploma as equivalent to a degree in aeronautical engineering. Clarifying with them could help correct any misconceptions in their understanding of your qualifications.
[23/11/2023, 08:51:49] Andie: Based on some reading up I did, there are some possible reasons why you may not be eligible for funding:

- You've already studied a higher education course before, and you *don't have any extra years of tuition fee support left.* (happened to me, I put in a CPR, Compelling Personal Reason to revert their decision) 

The number of years that you can get a Tuition Fee Loan is normally calculated as: *Length of current course + 1 year - number of years of previous study* Even if you only attended a course for a short time, it will still count as a year of previous study.

If you think that none of these reasons apply to you, you should contact student finance and ask them to explain their decision, which will reveal the discrepancy.

You may need to provide evidence of your previous qualifications and the course you're applying for. You can also appeal the decision if you think it's unfair or incorrectz

Going back to uni or repeating a year - GOV.UK. https://www.gov.uk/guidance/going-back-to-uni-or-repeating-a-year.

Going back to uni or repeating a year | Undergraduate | UCAS. https://www.ucas.com/finance/student-finance-england/going-back-uni-or-repeating-year.

[24/01/2024, 09:46:19] Andie: I came across this, this morning and I find it very much applies to the framework at which you should be operating
[25/01/2024, 06:42:50] Andie: Strategy - A clear plan of action on how to take the business/your affairs from where they are right now, to where you want it to be

Systems - The processes required that take your strategy from just 'wishful thinking' and turn it into an actual set of actions that produce results

Delegation - There is a point any business/affairs gets to where being a 'one man band' just won't cut it anymore. It's time to share the vision with others and build a team

Automation - Once you have a system that's working and a great team, the final part is finding ways to make business processes work on autopilot. 

Automation mean less time is spent in mundane takes and more on things that actually move the needle

‚Äé[11/03/2024, 15:21:05] Hope: ‚Äéaudio omitted
‚Äé[11/03/2024, 15:21:58] Hope: ‚Äéaudio omitted
[11/03/2024, 15:22:01] Hope: Central sensitization is a process in which the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) becomes hypersensitive to pain and other stimuli. It is a phenomenon associated with conditions like fibromyalgia, where the nervous system amplifies and misinterprets normal signals, leading to heightened sensitivity.

In central sensitization, the nerves in the central nervous system become more responsive and can overreact to stimuli, including those that are not typically painful. This heightened sensitivity can result in an increased perception of pain and discomfort. Factors like genetics, environmental triggers, and repeated exposure to pain or stress can contribute to the development of central sensitization.

Understanding central sensitization is crucial in conditions like fibromyalgia because it helps explain the widespread pain experienced by individuals. Healthcare professionals may employ various strategies to address central sensitization, including medications, physical therapy, and lifestyle modifications, to help manage and alleviate symptoms associated with heightened pain sensitivity.
[11/03/2024, 15:25:35] Hope: And my thing is hyper algesia
[11/03/2024, 15:25:41] Hope: Not hyper sensitivity
[11/03/2024, 16:00:57] Andie: Will prolly discuss this more when I figure out a bit better what it really is
[11/03/2024, 16:01:09] Andie: Thanks for your perspective
[11/03/2024, 16:01:19] Andie: It was good to hear
[11/03/2024, 16:01:37] Andie: And this is crazy to believe wow

[11/03/2024, 16:06:18] Hope: The condition is fibromyalgia, but one of the symptoms or brunches of it is the hyperalgesia.

So it could be a issue with the nerves or an issue with the discs on the neck. 

Basically only way to combat it is to find the main issue

[03/04/2024, 21:32:37] Andie: What you are investigating appears to be a medical report displaying the results of blood tests, specifically immunoglobulin levels. Here's an explanation of the relevant information:

The immunoglobulin G (IgG) level is reported as 18.0 g/L, which is higher than the provided reference range of 6.0 - 16.0 g/L. An elevated IgG level can indicate conditions like connective tissue diseases, sarcoidosis, certain liver diseases, or retroviral infections.

The immunoglobulin A (IgA) level is 1.81 g/L, which falls within the normal reference range of 0.8 - 2.8 g/L.

The immunoglobulin M (IgM) level is 1.04 g/L, also within the normal range of 0.5 - 1.9 g/L.

Despite the abnormal IgG result, the report states "No Further Action" is needed, likely because the patient is clinically well. However, the raised IgG level may warrant further investigation or monitoring by the healthcare provider to identify any underlying conditions.

The specimen details indicate it was collected on March 27, 2024, and received the following day for analysis.

Overall, this report communicates abnormal but non-critical immunoglobulin test results that suggest potential health issues worth exploring further if symptoms arise.

[09/04/2024, 20:49:31] Andie: Oh my gosh Oppy look at this
[09/04/2024, 20:49:48] Andie: Individuals with ADHD or ADD often seek activities that provide a quick dopamine boost to help alleviate their symptoms. Some common dopamine-seeking activities for people with ADHD or ADD include:

	1.	Novelty Seeking: Engaging in new and exciting experiences to stimulate the brain‚Äôs reward system.
	2.	Hyperfocus: Becoming deeply absorbed in tasks or activities that are highly stimulating or interesting.
	3.	Risk-Taking Behaviors: Participating in activities that provide an adrenaline rush, such as extreme sports or impulsive decision-making.
	4.	Video Games: Playing video games can provide immediate gratification and excitement, making them appealing to individuals with ADHD.
	5.	Socializing: Seeking out social interactions that provide stimulation and engagement.
	6.	Creative Pursuits: Activities like art, music, or writing can offer a creative outlet and a sense of accomplishment.
	7.	Physical Activities: Exercise and sports can help release pent-up energy and boost mood through the release of endorphins and dopamine.
	8.	Multitasking: Juggling multiple tasks or activities simultaneously can provide a sense of stimulation and accomplishment, albeit sometimes leading to overwhelm.
	9.	Problem-Solving: Engaging in activities that involve problem-solving and quick thinking, such as puzzles or strategy games.
	10.	Impulse Buying: Shopping or spending money impulsively can provide a temporary dopamine rush.

It‚Äôs important for individuals with ADHD or ADD to find healthy and sustainable ways to manage their symptoms and seek dopamine, as some activities, like excessive risk-taking or impulsive behaviors, can have negative consequences.

[01/05/2024, 08:35:12] Andie: Morningg Opprah
[01/05/2024, 08:35:23] Andie: onto opening an email
[01/05/2024, 08:35:36] Andie: few known methods are
[01/05/2024, 08:36:16] Andie: To open an .eml file, you can use the following steps:

Windows:

Double-click the .eml file to open it in your default email program (e.g. Outlook, Windows Mail, etc.).
If the file doesn't open automatically, you can right-click the file, select "Open with", and choose your email program.
[01/05/2024, 08:36:24] Andie: macOS:

Double-click the .eml file to open it in your default email program (e.g. Apple Mail).
If the file doesn't open automatically, you can right-click (or Control+click) the file, select "Open with", and choose your email program.
[01/05/2024, 08:36:29] Andie: Web-based email:

If you're using a web-based email service (e.g. Gmail, Outlook.com, Yahoo Mail), you can usually attach the .eml file to a new email and send it to yourself or someone else.

Some web-based email services may also allow you to drag and drop the .eml file directly into the email composition window.

[16/05/2024, 20:32:25] Hope: Sorry long paragraph ahead
[16/05/2024, 20:32:34] Hope: But this explains me to a tea
[16/05/2024, 20:32:36] Hope: When your brain processes information faster than your eyes can read, it can lead to specific difficulties, especially with reading long paragraphs or navigating back and forth on screens. Here‚Äôs a detailed look at how this discrepancy affects reading and some potential strategies to manage it:

### Effects on Reading Long Paragraphs

1. **Cognitive Overload**: Your brain may quickly grasp the general idea or keywords in a text, but this rapid processing can create a sense of overload if the eyes can't keep up. This can make it hard to focus on the details within long paragraphs.

2. **Impatience and Frustration**: The feeling that your brain is ahead of your eyes can lead to impatience and frustration. This may result in skipping parts of the text or not fully engaging with the material, leading to gaps in understanding.

3. **Loss of Context**: Rapid cognitive processing might cause you to anticipate or infer information that isn‚Äôt there, leading to misunderstandings or misinterpretations, especially in detailed or nuanced content.

4. **Difficulty with Sequential Processing**: Reading requires following a sequence of words and sentences. If your brain is jumping ahead, maintaining this sequence can be challenging, causing you to lose track of where you are in the text.

### Effects on Navigating Screens

1. **Screen Scrolling**: On digital devices, your brain may want to skip ahead or scroll quickly through content. This can make it hard to engage with each part of the text and disrupts the flow of reading.

2. **Back-and-Forth Navigation**: Moving back and forth on screens (e.g., switching between tabs or sections) can be particularly challenging because it requires reorienting yourself each time. The brain‚Äôs quick processing may not allow enough time to fully register and retain information from each section.

### Strategies to Manage Discrepancies

1. **Pacing Techniques**: Use a finger or a pointer to guide your eyes while reading. This can help synchronize the pace of your reading with your cognitive processing speed.

2. **Chunking Information**: Break down long paragraphs into smaller, manageable chunks. Take brief pauses to reflect on each chunk before moving on, which can help keep your brain and eyes aligned.

3. **Summarizing and Note-Taking**: Periodically pause to summarize what you‚Äôve read or take notes. This can slow down your reading process, ensuring better comprehension and retention.

4. **Mindfulness Practices**: Practice mindfulness or meditation to help slow down your thought processes. Techniques that emphasize being present can help bring your cognitive processing more in line with your reading speed.

5. **Visual Aids and Tools**: Utilize tools like reading strips, digital highlighters, or software that paces the text for you. These aids can help keep your reading focused and structured.

6. **Optimize Screen Settings**: Adjust your screen settings to reduce glare and eye strain. Use features like "reader mode" or "focus mode" that simplify the layout and reduce distractions.

7. **Regular Breaks**: Take regular breaks to avoid cognitive fatigue. This can help maintain a steadier pace between your brain's processing speed and your reading speed.

If these strategies are not sufficient, consider consulting with a cognitive specialist or therapist who can offer tailored strategies and interventions to help manage the disparity between your cognitive processing speed and reading pace.

[16/05/2024, 21:48:54] Hope: Certainly! Here‚Äôs an explanation of **Processing Speed Discrepancy**:

### Processing Speed Discrepancy

**Processing Speed Discrepancy** refers to a situation where there is a mismatch between the speed at which your brain processes information and the speed at which sensory input (like reading or listening) is received. This discrepancy can cause difficulties in effectively understanding and responding to information.

### Why It Happens

1. **Cognitive Processing Speed**: This is how quickly your brain can understand and make sense of information. Some people have a very high cognitive processing speed, meaning their brain can quickly grasp concepts, predict outcomes, and make connections.

2. **Sensory Input Speed**: This is the rate at which your senses (such as vision and hearing) take in information. Reading involves moving your eyes across text, and listening involves processing spoken words sequentially.

When these two speeds are not aligned, you might experience:

- **Frustration**: Your brain is ready to move on to the next idea before your eyes have finished reading the current text or before the speaker has finished their point. This can cause impatience and difficulty staying focused.
- **Loss of Context**: Because your brain processes information quickly, it might skip over details or fail to fully comprehend the context, leading to misunderstandings or incomplete information retention.
- **Difficulty with Long Texts or Dialogues**: Long paragraphs or extended listening can be particularly challenging because the discrepancy becomes more pronounced over time, making it hard to maintain consistent understanding.

### Effects on Daily Activities

- **Reading**: You may find yourself re-reading sections because your eyes can't keep up with how quickly your brain is processing the information. This can make reading long paragraphs especially tedious and hard to follow.
- **Listening**: During conversations or lectures, you might zone out or miss details because your brain is anticipating and moving ahead of the speaker, causing you to lose track of the dialogue.
- **Screen Navigation**: Moving between different sections of text or tabs on a screen can disrupt the flow of information, making it harder to stay engaged and comprehend the material.

### Strategies to Manage Processing Speed Discrepancy

1. **Pacing Techniques**: Use a finger or a pointer to guide your reading, which can help slow down your eye movements to match your brain's processing speed.
2. **Chunking Information**: Break down long texts into smaller sections and take brief pauses to reflect on each chunk before moving on. This helps your brain process information in manageable pieces.
3. **Active Engagement**: Summarize what you read or hear in your own words periodically. This active engagement can help synchronize your cognitive processing with the sensory input.
4. **Mindfulness Practices**: Techniques that focus on being present, such as mindfulness or meditation, can help align your thought processes with the pace of reading or listening.
5. **Visual Aids and Tools**: Use reading strips, digital highlighters, or software that paces the text for you, helping to maintain focus and manage the flow of information.

By employing these strategies, you can help bridge the gap between your brain‚Äôs fast processing and the slower pace of sensory input, making it easier to follow along with reading and conversations.

[19/05/2024, 17:12:26] Andie: Dr. Andrew Huberman, a neuroscientist and professor at Stanford University, emphasizes the importance of morning light exposure for regulating the circadian rhythm. He often advises people to go outside within the first hour of waking up, without checking their phones or other devices, to get natural sunlight. This practice can help improve sleep patterns, mood, and overall health by synchronizing the internal body clock with the natural light-dark cycle.

In various interviews and podcasts, Huberman explains how natural light exposure in the morning helps regulate cortisol levels and enhance wakefulness, while also setting the stage for better sleep at night. The direct reaction to sunlight at specific times of the day is a key aspect of maintaining a healthy circadian rhythm, which is crucial for optimal cognitive and physical performance.

[22/05/2024, 08:06:57] Andie: *Conclusion of Research*

These studies show that it‚Äôs not just how much time you spend on social media that can make ADHD symptoms worse, but how you use social media. 

For example, if you‚Äôre constantly checking your phone and getting distracted, this can increase your ADHD symptoms. 

Anxiety and poor sleep are important factors in this relationship. 

If social media use makes you anxious or disrupts your sleep, it can make ADHD symptoms worse. 

Additionally, the way this relationship works suggests that using social media in a problematic way can lead to more ADHD symptoms over time. 

So, addressing how social media is used, like setting limits and having good sleep habits, may be crucial in managing ADHD symptoms effectively. ‚Äé<This message was edited>
[22/05/2024, 08:57:39] Hope: I can see this now definitely

[22/05/2024, 09:05:40] Andie: https://youtu.be/NUMa0QkPzns?si=UhMEK9-9zNsLf6QW
[22/05/2024, 09:05:47] Andie: It is by design
[22/05/2024, 09:05:55] Andie: Not just social media the entirety of the smartphone
‚Äé[22/05/2024, 09:09:50] Andie: ‚Äéimage omitted
[22/05/2024, 09:11:33] Andie: *Conclusion*

The research on smartphone addiction shows that it‚Äôs a complicated issue with many different aspects. 

While some people use their smartphones too much, calling this behavior an addiction is still debated. 

People often rely on smartphones for information, entertainment, and staying connected with others. 

For example, someone might constantly check their phone for social media updates or new messages. This heavy use can have serious psychological effects, like making people feel bad about themselves or causing depression, especially in those who are already vulnerable. 

However, because there are no clear rules for diagnosing smartphone addiction and there is still some confusion about what exactly it is, more research is needed to better understand and deal with this problem.
‚Äé[22/05/2024, 09:14:20] Andie: ‚Äéimage omitted
‚Äé[22/05/2024, 09:14:20] Andie: ‚Äéimage omitted
[22/05/2024, 09:15:36] Andie: *Conclusion*

Research shows that using social media can be similar to being addicted to cocaine. 

For instance, people might feel compelled to check social media all the time, experience negative emotions like anxiety or depression, and feel uneasy or stressed when they can‚Äôt use it. 

Although social media and drugs like cocaine are very different, the way people can become addicted and how it affects their lives are quite similar. 

This means that, even though social media addiction is not the same as drug addiction, it has enough in common that it should be taken seriously and treated with similar concern and interventions. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[23/05/2024, 15:07:38] Andie: 1.	Compliance and Legal:

	‚Ä¢	Alternative 

Qualifications: Consider certifications like the ICA Certificate in Compliance or CCEP (Certified Compliance and Ethics Professional).

	‚Ä¢	Transferable Skills: If you have experience in fields like finance, operations, or risk management, emphasize your understanding of regulations, attention to detail, and analytical skills.

	‚Ä¢	Networking: Connect with professionals in compliance and attend relevant industry events to learn about opportunities and gain insights.

	2.	Tax and Controllers:

	‚Ä¢	Certifications: Pursue qualifications like ATT (Association of Taxation Technicians) or CTA (Chartered Tax Adviser) which are respected in the UK.

	‚Ä¢	Experience: Highlight any experience in finance, bookkeeping, or managing budgets, as these are transferable to tax and controllers roles.
	‚Ä¢	Professional 

Development: Online courses or part-time study can help you gain necessary skills without a traditional accounting degree.

	3.	Corporate Risk:

	‚Ä¢	Certifications: Consider obtaining the IRM Certificate in Risk Management or other relevant risk management certifications.

	‚Ä¢	Skills Transfer: Emphasize experience in project management, strategic planning, or any role involving risk assessment or mitigation.

	‚Ä¢	Networking: Join risk management associations and attend seminars to build your network and learn about opportunities.

	4.	Global Banking & Markets:

	‚Ä¢	Education and 

Certifications: Short courses in finance or investment, or pursuing CFA (Chartered Financial Analyst) certifications can be helpful.

	‚Ä¢	Experience: Roles in sales, business development, or data analysis can provide relevant skills.

	‚Ä¢	Networking: Attend finance industry events and join relevant professional groups to meet key industry players.

	5.	Regional Audit and 

Enterprise Audit:

	‚Ä¢	Certifications: Obtaining qualifications like the CIA (Certified Internal Auditor) can make you a strong candidate.

	‚Ä¢	Transferable Experience: Experience in roles that require attention to detail, process improvement, or regulatory compliance can be beneficial.

	‚Ä¢	Professional Development: Enroll in auditing courses or workshops, and consider volunteering for audit-related tasks in your current role.

[28/05/2024, 22:05:07] Andie: Based on the job description and our conversation, it seems this Internal Audit (Business) Analyst role at Goldman Sachs may be a bit unconventional compared to a typical internal audit position. A few key points:

1. Your current experience, while not directly in auditing, seems to have transferable skills that caught their attention - things like ensuring compliance, supporting projects end-to-end, process improvements, working in diverse teams, etc. They likely see potential in your ability to learn and adapt.

2. The role emphasizes assisting in audits rather than leading them. Phrases like "Assist in every step of an audit" and "Collaborate and work as a team" suggest you'll be learning and supporting rather than expected to be an audit expert from day one. 

3. They are looking for an analytical mindset, ownership, motivation to learn the business, and relevant certifications/education are a "plus" - not a firm requirement. This aligns with choosing someone with potential.

4. The ambiguity in the JD around specific audit knowledge could mean they are open to non-traditional candidates who demonstrate the key competencies.

For the interview, I'd focus on:

- Highlighting transferable skills from your current role
- Expressing eagerness to learn audit methodology and the business 
- Preparing examples of your analytical skills, teamwork and ownership
- Knowing your CV inside out and tying it to the role
- Brushing up on basic audit concepts to demonstrate interest
- Being honest about knowledge gaps but confident in your ability to learn

Remember, they chose to interview you based on your unique background. Be confident in what you bring to the table while showing humility and a learning mindset for new areas. Wishing you the best! Let me know if you have any other questions.

[28/05/2024, 22:08:10] Andie: Certainly! Let's break down the job description section by section to better understand the role and expectations.

*Introduction* :
- Defines Internal Audit's mission as the third line of defense, assessing the firm's control structure, governance, risk management, and compliance 
- Highlights key responsibilities: communicating effectiveness of controls, raising risk awareness, assessing control culture and conduct, and monitoring control measures
- Describes the diverse background of the Internal Audit team

This suggests the role is part of a comprehensive risk management framework, working with various aspects of the business.

*Who We Look For* :
- Emphasizes strong risk and control mindset, analytical abilities, professional skepticism, and ability to challenge and discuss with management
- Seeks innovative thinkers who can enhance audit techniques, build relationships, and thrive in a team-oriented, fast-paced environment

They are looking for candidates who can think critically, bring fresh perspectives, and effectively communicate with stakeholders.

*How You Will Fulfil Your Potential* :
- Collaborate across EMEA region
- Develop deep understanding of the business and products
- Assist in all stages of an audit (scoping, planning, fieldwork, reporting)
- Conduct walkthroughs and control design assessments
- Execute testing and document work
- Identify risks, assess controls, and recommend improvements
- Prepare and present audit conclusions to management
- Follow up on open audit issues
- Participate in initiatives to improve audit processes

This section outlines the day-to-day responsibilities and the overall audit lifecycle involvement. It emphasizes the collaborative and cross-functional nature of the role.

*Skills And Experience We Are Looking For* :
- 1-2 years of experience in auditing controls or related control functions
- Team-oriented with strong ownership and ability to work independently
- Accurate, accountable, and able to manage multiple tasks
- Interest in learning about financial services and controls
- Highly motivated with strong analytical skills and quick learning ability
- Relevant certification a plus
- Graduate degree preferred, open to various disciplines

The requirements emphasize potential and transferable skills over direct audit experience. They are open to candidates from related control functions and various educational backgrounds.

*Teams Available* :
- Lists potential teams the role could support
- Invites candidates to express team preferences

*This flexibility suggests they are open to aligning the role with the candidate's interests and background* .

In summary, while the job description includes traditional audit elements, it also leaves room for interpretation and emphasizes the candidate's potential, transferable skills, and learning mindset. The ambiguity may be intentional to attract a diverse candidate pool and tailor the role to the individual's strengths.
[28/05/2024, 22:10:36] Andie: Here's a breakdown of the key jargon and concepts in the job description, with examples to clarify their meaning:

1. *Third Line Of Defence:* 
   - In the "three lines of defense" model, Internal Audit is the third line, providing independent assurance. 
   - Example: Internal Audit reviews the work of the first line (business operations) and second line (risk management and compliance functions) to ensure effective risk management.

2. *Governance Processes:* 
   - Refers to the systems in place for decision-making, accountability, and control within an organization.
   - Example: Reviewing the effectiveness of the board of directors' oversight of risk management practices.

3. *Risk Management Framework:*
   - The processes and structures used to identify, assess, mitigate, and monitor risks.
   - Example: Evaluating whether the company's risk assessment methodology effectively captures all relevant risks.

4. *Capital and Anti-financial Crime Frameworks:*
   - Refers to the policies and procedures related to maintaining adequate capital and preventing financial crimes like money laundering or fraud.
   - Example: Testing the company's customer due diligence procedures to ensure compliance with anti-money laundering regulations.

5. *Control Culture and Conduct Risks:*
   - Control culture refers to the shared attitudes and behaviors that determine how an organization approaches risk management and internal control.
   - Conduct risk is the risk of inappropriate, unethical, or unlawful behavior by employees.
   - Example: Assessing whether the tone set by leadership promotes a strong ethical culture and adherence to controls.

6. *Walkthroughs:*
   - A walkthrough involves step-by-step review of a process or transaction from start to finish to understand and document the flow of information and associated controls.
   - Example: Performing a walkthrough of the company's trade confirmation process to identify any control gaps.

7. *Control Design Assessments:*
   - Evaluating whether the controls in place are designed effectively to mitigate the relevant risks.
   - Example: Reviewing the approval matrix for wire transfers to ensure appropriate segregation of duties.

8. *Audit Fieldwork:*
   - The phase of an audit where evidence is collected and evaluated to support the audit's conclusions.
   - Example: Reviewing a sample of expense reports to test the effectiveness of the company's expense approval controls.

9. *Audit Issues:*
   - Findings or concerns identified during an audit that require management's attention and remediation.
   - Example: Discovering that user access rights are not being removed timely when employees change roles, resulting in an audit issue.

10. *COSO Framework:*
    - Stands for the Committee of Sponsoring Organizations of the Treadway Commission. It's a widely recognized framework for designing and evaluating internal controls.
    - Example: Using the COSO framework to assess whether the company's control environment, risk assessment, control activities, information and communication, and monitoring are effective.

11. *SOX Compliance:*
    - Refers to the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, which requires certain companies to maintain and assess the effectiveness of their internal controls over financial reporting.
    - Example: Testing key controls over financial statement closing process to support SOX compliance.
[28/05/2024, 22:13:30] Andie: Imagine you're a recent graduate or someone with a couple years of experience in a related field, like risk management or compliance testing. You're interested in a career at Goldman Sachs, a leading global investment bank, and you come across this Internal Audit (Business) Analyst role based in Birmingham, UK.

You start reading the job description and see that Internal Audit is described as the "third line of defense." This might be new to you, but essentially, it means that Internal Audit is responsible for providing independent assurance over the work of the first line (the business units) and the second line (risk management and compliance). In other words, Internal Audit's job is to make sure that the risks are properly identified and managed across the firm.

The job description mentions that Internal Audit reviews things like the firm's governance processes, risk management framework, and controls around capital and financial crime prevention. These are all critical areas for a financial institution like Goldman Sachs. For example, governance processes refer to how decisions are made and overseen at the highest levels of the company. Risk management framework is about how the firm identifies, measures, and mitigates various risks, like market risk or credit risk. Capital and financial crime controls are about ensuring the firm has enough financial resources and isn't involved in any illegal activities like money laundering.

You read on and see that Goldman Sachs is looking for candidates with strong analytical skills, who are able to work well in teams, and who can communicate effectively with management. They want people who are eager to learn about the financial services industry and who can quickly grasp new business processes and systems. This is exciting to you because you're a quick learner and you're curious to know more about how a global investment bank works.

The job description then goes into more detail about what you'd be doing day-to-day. You'd be collaborating with audit teams across Europe, the Middle East, and Africa, so there's an international component. You'd be diving deep into understanding specific businesses and products that you'd be auditing. 

When it comes to actual audit work, you'd be involved in all stages. This includes scoping (figuring out what areas to focus on), planning (deciding how to approach the audit), fieldwork (actually testing the controls), and reporting (communicating the results). Specific tasks could include:

- Conducting walkthroughs: This is where you sit down with the people who actually perform a process, like trading a financial product, and have them walk you through it step-by-step. This helps you understand how it works in practice and identify any potential risks or control weaknesses.

- Control design assessments: This is about evaluating whether the controls that are in place are designed effectively. For example, if there's a control that requires two people to sign off on a large payment, you'd assess whether that control is sufficient to prevent unauthorized payments.

- Testing: This is where you actually try out the controls to see if they're working as intended. For example, you might sample a bunch of new client accounts to see if the proper approval process was followed.

Throughout all this, you'd be looking for any risks or areas for improvement, and recommending solutions to management.

The job description also mentions opportunities to get involved in department-wide projects to improve how Internal Audit works. This could include things like developing new data analytics techniques to identify risks more effectively, or streamlining the audit process to be more efficient.

Finally, the job description lists some of the specific teams you could be working with, like Compliance, Tax, and Corporate Risk. This gives you a sense of the breadth of areas you could be exposed to.

Overall, this role seems to offer a great mix of learning opportunities, hands-on experience, and exposure to senior management at a leading financial firm. It's a chance to develop a deep understanding of how a complex, global organization manages risk, and to help strengthen its controls and processes. While it might seem a little daunting at first, especially if you don't have direct audit experience, the firm seems open to candidates with diverse backgrounds and a willingness to learn. It could be a great stepping stone into a career in finance, risk management, or internal audit.

[29/05/2024, 12:24:20] Andie: Based on the new information that the specific role you're interviewing for is Regional Audit Analyst, there are a few key differences and additional considerations compared to our previous discussion about the Internal Audit (Business) Analyst role:

*Scope* : As a Regional Audit Analyst, your focus may be more on auditing processes and controls specific to a particular geographic region, rather than the broader business operations. This could involve understanding regional regulations, business practices, and risk factors.

*Collaboration* : You may work more closely with regional teams and stakeholders, in addition to the global Internal Audit function. Building relationships and effectively communicating with regional management could be particularly important.

*Travel* : Depending on the specific region you're covering, there may be some travel involved to conduct audits or meet with local teams. Be prepared to discuss your willingness and ability to travel if needed.

*Language and Cultural Skills* : If the region you're covering includes countries where English isn't the primary language, language skills or cultural awareness could be valuable assets. Consider highlighting any relevant language capabilities or international experience.

*Adaptability* : Regional business environments can vary significantly. Emphasize your ability to adapt to new contexts, understand local nuances, and apply global audit principles to regional situations.

However, many of the core aspects of the role likely remain similar to what we discussed before:

You'll still be part of the third line of defense, providing independent assurance over risks and controls.

The job will involve risk assessment, control testing, and communicating findings and recommendations to management.

Strong analytical skills, attention to detail, and the ability to learn new things will be important.

Your experience at Deloitte, particularly in ensuring compliance, managing projects, and improving processes, remains highly relevant.

As you prepare for the interview, consider framing your responses to highlight not just your technical audit and business skills, but also your ability to navigate regional complexities, build cross-geographic relationships, and adapt audit approaches as needed.

*Some additional questions to consider* :

What do you know about the specific region this role covers? 

Are there any particular economic, regulatory, or business trends that could impact the audit approach?

Have you worked on any projects or with any clients that spanned multiple geographies? 

How did you handle the complexities?

How do you build effective working relationships with stakeholders from different cultural backgrounds?
How do you ensure audit quality and consistency when working across different regional contexts?

Remember, the interviewers will likely be assessing not just your technical fit for the role, but also your potential to grow and lead within the regional audit team over time. 

Demonstrate your eagerness to learn, your flexibility, and your commitment to adding value through the audit process. ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[18/06/2024, 06:41:26] Andie: Factors like genetics, environment, personal experiences, and even individual biology play a role in how these conditions manifest. This variability means that symptoms, severity, and the impact on daily life can differ widely from person to person.
[18/06/2024, 06:41:52] Andie: so definitely it comes in different flavors, more often than not
[18/06/2024, 06:43:10] Andie: there are common symptoms and patterns that tend to emerge, as illustrated by the man in his talk. His experiences of manic episodes, characterized by symptoms like grandiosity, lack of sleep, racing thoughts, and high-risk behaviors, are typical of bipolar disorder. Likewise, the alternating periods of depression, marked by feelings of hopelessness, lack of energy, and difficulty functioning, are also commonly observed in those with bipolar disorder.

While these symptoms are often consistent among individuals with bipolar disorder, the specifics‚Äîsuch as the frequency, duration, and triggers of episodes‚Äîcan vary. This is why recognizing both the shared symptoms and the individual variations is important for understanding and managing the condition effectively.

[29/06/2024, 11:57:06] Andie: *The Four Intersections*

At the intersections of these elements, you find:

	‚Ä¢	Passion: Where what you love and what you are good at intersect.

	‚Ä¢	Mission: Where what you love and what the world needs intersect.

	‚Ä¢	Vocation: Where what the world needs and what you can be paid for intersect.

	‚Ä¢	Profession: Where what you are good at and what you can be paid for intersect.
[29/06/2024, 11:58:47] Andie: *How to Use This Concept*

So for you who is uncertain about life after an aerospace degree, using the Ikigai framework might help clarify the path forward:

	1.	Reflect on what you love: Think about what excites you, even outside of your degree. It could be hobbies, interests, or subjects you are passionate about.

	2.	Assess your skills: Consider both technical skills from your degree and personal strengths. What are you naturally good at?

	3.	Identify the needs: Look at the world around you. What issues or areas could benefit from your skills and passions? Where can you make a meaningful impact?

	4.	Evaluate potential careers: Explore professions that align with your interests, skills, and societal needs. 

Research different paths within and outside of aerospace that could be financially viable.

By examining these areas, you can begin to identify intersections and ultimately find a direction that resonates with all four elements of Ikigai. This process might not yield immediate answers, but it can provide valuable insights and guide future decisions in an informed true to your core way.

African healthcare systems have excessively high patient-to-doctor ratios and prevalent diseases and severely inadequate numbers of radiologists. They will fine-tune a multimodal LLM applied to radiology and medical imaging using a supervised approach with a labeled dataset of medical images and corresponding reports collected from facilities across Ghana and Africa.

[06/09/2024, 05:15:50] Andie: No, it‚Äôs not possible to hide your updated experience from your connections while only making it visible to recruiters on LinkedIn, especially with a free account. Your connections can see any changes you make to your profile, although you can prevent notifications from being sent to your network when you update your experience.
[06/09/2024, 05:15:51] Andie: However, you can enable the "Open to Work" feature, which allows you to privately signal to recruiters that you‚Äôre open to job opportunities without making that information visible to your connections.
[06/09/2024, 05:16:12] Andie: Basically on LinkedIn, you can update your experience without notifying your network. To do this:

Go to your profile and edit your experience.

When you update your role, make sure to toggle off the option that says ‚ÄúShare with network‚Äù or ‚ÄúNotify your network‚Äù to prevent an update notification from being sent out.

[24/09/2024, 18:43:09] Andie: About this
[24/09/2024, 18:44:04] Andie: Got some general steps for u
[24/09/2024, 18:46:09] Andie: ## Sharing Your Calendar

1. Open Outlook and navigate to the Calendar view

2. Click on the "Share" button at the top of the calendar view

3. In the "Share with" box, type the name or email address of the person you want to share your calendar with

4. Choose the level of access you want to grant:

   - *Can view when I'm busy*: Shows only your availability, without details

   - *Can view titles and locations*: Shows when you're busy, plus event titles and locations

   - *Can view all details*: Allows the person to see all information in your calendar

   - *Can edit*:Gives permission to make changes to your calendar

   - *Delegate*: Allows the person to edit your calendar and share it with others

5. Click "Send" to share your calendar

[23/12/2024, 12:49:30] Andie: Typical DCD/Dyspraxia-related forgetfulness scenarios that match my descriptions:

*Sequential Task Forgetfulness:*

Starting to make tea, putting the kettle on, then completely forgetting you were making tea and finding the kettle boiled hours later
Going upstairs to get something specific, arriving upstairs and having no idea what you went up for
Starting to write an email, getting distracted mid-sentence, then completely losing track of what you were trying to communicate

*Working Memory Issues:*

Someone tells you a room number or phone extension at work, but by the time you reach for a pen it's gone
Can't hold numbers in your head to do mental math - they seem to "slip away"
Having to immediately write down or act on information because if you wait even a few seconds, it vanishes

*Task Sequencing Memory:*

Knowing how to do something but suddenly "forgetting" the steps mid-task
Having to consciously think through the order of getting dressed
Losing track of where you are in a familiar task if interrupted

*Daily Life Impact:*

Repeatedly checking if you've locked doors because you can't remember doing it
Forgetting items you use daily (keys, phone) despite having specific places for them
Missing appointments despite having them written down
Losing track of time while doing tasks ‚Äé<This message was edited>

[06/03/2025, 21:36:47] Andie: I found a similar project online and someone prompting saying the following:

Context

Many young people in Sierra Leone have skills and talents but lack digital platforms to monetize them. This PWA marketplace will serve as a bridge between service providers and clients, enabling users to earn income through freelancing, digital services, and skill-based jobs. The platform should integrate local mobile money solutions (such as Orange Money and Afrimoney) alongside global payment methods (such as PayPal and Stripe) to facilitate seamless transactions.

Since mobile devices are the primary means of internet access in Sierra Leone, the application must be lightweight, mobile-first, and optimized for low data consumption. The offline capabilities should allow users to view profiles, services, and messages even without an active internet connection.

Security, ease of use, and efficiency are top priorities, ensuring that users feel confident in using the platform to grow their income

Getaway‚Äôs brand story unfolds through a visually captivating metaphor: from the chaos of a Big Bang emerges calm, symbolising the transformation from the stress of trip planning to the order and ease our platform brings. 

With a dynamic particle-based animation at 60 frame per second, users interact through touch or mouse, scattering particles that resiliently reform into an airplane; reinforcing our promise of stability amid travel uncertainty. 

Carefully timed transitions.from particle chaos to brand reveal spark curiosity, build anticipation, and deliver a memorable, novel experience that mirrors the seamless journey Getaway provides.

	‚Ä¢	*Quantitative Analyst* (Quant) ‚Äì Common in finance and investment banking, these roles involve modelling financial data and risk, often using complex maths.

	‚Ä¢	*Actuary* ‚Äì Uses probability and statistical methods to assess risk, especially in insurance and finance.

	‚Ä¢	*Operations Research Analyst* ‚Äì Applies mathematical techniques to decision-making, logistics, or efficiency problems (used in supply chains, transport, etc.).

	‚Ä¢	*Economist / Statistician* ‚Äì Heavy on mathematics, modelling, and analysis, especially around economic policy, market trends, or demographic data.

[10/10/2025, 20:31:44] Andie: Social media platforms exploit and amplify these tendencies through algorithmic reinforcement, which rewards engagement with visibility and dopamine feedback loops.
[10/10/2025, 20:32:56] Andie: It‚Äôs a behavioural science engineered to be inherently addictive; comparable to gambling, but scaled globally through digital networks.

[10/10/2025, 20:39:48] Andie: Psychologists like Jean Twenge and W. Keith Campbell have written about this in The Narcissism Epidemic, linking it to social media culture.

‚Äé[17/11/2025, 21:48:51] Hope: ‚Äéaudio omitted
[18/11/2025, 11:53:19] Andie: Thanks Oppy! Yh im still looking into the whole right to choose with my GP. It does seem feasible but it looks like Id still need to have forms they gave me completed and then at the referral point call on this thing your saying? Does that sound about right?
[18/11/2025, 13:16:52] Hope: I received this from my GP, 

Something for you to keep in mind too. 

Good afternoon, Opprah.
Apologies for the delay in response. We have been advised the following as per below with regards to the concerns you have noted:
Rationale for declining shared care in this case:
Shared care agreements are designed for NHS specialist services. NICE guideline NG87 (Attention Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder: diagnosis and management) states that shared care should be considered where a patient is stable and the specialist provides a clear treatment plan. This presumes the specialist is part of the NHS pathway.
Private diagnoses do not automatically transfer into NHS prescribing. NHS England and multiple ICBs have confirmed that GPs are not obliged to prescribe ADHD medication following a private assessment. Patients who choose private routes are expected to continue prescribing with that provider.
Clinical expertise and monitoring requirements. ADHD medications are controlled drugs with significant monitoring needs (blood pressure, pulse, weight, side effects, efficacy). Practices are not resourced or trained to provide this monitoring outside of an NHS specialist framework.
Contractual and funding limitations. Prescribing ADHD medication after private diagnosis is not part of the GMS contract. We do not hold the prescribing budget or capacity for the required monitoring.
Patient safety. Responsibility for prescribing must remain with the diagnosing specialist until the patient is formally accepted into NHS services.
Alternative NHS pathways available to patients:
Referral to local NHS ADHD services for assessment and treatment initiation.
Use of the NHS ‚ÄúRight to Choose‚Äù pathway, which allows referral to certain providers commissioned by the NHS.
Until such referral is accepted, prescribing and monitoring should remain with the private provider.
Summary position:  Our practice will only accept shared care requests from NHS providers, and even then, acceptance depends on our clinical expertise and capacity to monitor the patient safely. ADHD medication following private diagnosis remains the responsibility of the private prescriber. Patients wishing to access NHS prescribing should be referred via the Right to Choose pathway or local NHS ADHD services.
This position is consistent with NICE guidance, NHS England policy, and the contractual limitations of general practice.
Kind regards,

Bellevue Medical Centre

[05/12/2025, 13:17:29] Andie: the literal "Bible" for Silicon Valley engineers on how to build addictive products using casino logic, is:
"Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products" by Nir Eyal.
[05/12/2025, 13:17:52] Andie: Published in 2014, Hooked became required reading in Stanford's design school and was the go-to manual for thousands of startups. It wasn't left a secret. it was the curriculum.
[05/12/2025, 13:18:31] Andie: The core of the book is the "Hook Model," a four-step loop (Trigger‚Üí‚ÜíAction ‚Üí‚ÜíVariable Reward ‚Üí‚ÜíInvestment). ‚Äé<This message was edited>
[05/12/2025, 13:19:17] Andie: The "Variable Reward" step is a direct application of B.F. Skinner's research on operant conditioning‚Äîthe exact same psychological principle that makes slot machines addictive. You pull the lever (refresh the feed) not knowing what prize you'll get, and that uncertainty creates a dopamine-driven compulsion loop.
[05/12/2025, 13:19:33] Hope: Yes because in the whole continent there‚Äôs action. People are awake
‚Äé[05/12/2025, 13:19:46] Andie: ‚Äéimage omitted
[05/12/2025, 13:19:54] Andie: facts
[05/12/2025, 13:20:56] Andie: the real break down is this : 

Every addictive feature you see on a social media platform is a direct implementation of the Hook Model.

*The* *Trigger*: The red notification dot.

*The* *Action*: Opening the app.

*The* *Variable* *Reward*: Scrolling the feed‚Äîwill the next video be amazing or boring? Will I have likes? This is the slot machine.

*The* *Investment*: You post a photo or leave a comment, which loads the trigger for the next loop.

[05/12/2025, 13:29:33] Hope: Of being an ADHD brain in an attention economy. 

I have have a registered todo list in my mind of things I didn‚Äôt even put on my todo list
[05/12/2025, 13:29:43] Andie: A "Second Brain" is simply a trusted, external system to store your ideas. It could be a notes app (like Notion, Apple Notes), a physical notebook, or a Pinterest board.
[05/12/2025, 13:30:14] Andie: this is the visual version of an adhd creative board todo list
[05/12/2025, 13:30:25] Andie: rather than linear , non-linear cause adhd likes that
[05/12/2025, 13:30:48] Hope: My brain needs something it can hyperfocus on right now for example writing etc
[05/12/2025, 13:31:02] Hope: Pinterest for the lewks üòÖ
[05/12/2025, 13:31:11] Andie: "Your mind is for having ideas, not holding them."
‚Äî Tiago Forte

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=T6Mfl1OywM8
[05/12/2025, 13:31:20] Andie: it sounds good
[05/12/2025, 13:32:26] Hope: I must find solutions, that‚Äôs the brain I have. So maths works, fighting for human rights work.

[05/12/2025, 13:36:00] Andie: yup that's your reward function
[05/12/2025, 13:36:16] Andie: funny how it parallels a concept in Artificial Intelligence know as Reinforcement Learning
[05/12/2025, 13:44:01] Andie: What we're seeing is the visible manifestation of reinforcement learning. For the platforms, it's a tool to build a perfect profile of you, serving you more of the content that keeps you hooked. For you, it's a principle that can be applied externally: you can reinforce your own learning, your ability to public speak, or your advocacy for women's rights.
When you intentionally curate your feed, the platform's artificial loop and your natural growth loop reinforce each other in a positive direction. But the opposite is also true. Without intention, these same loops create the negative spirals and rabbit holes that consume us.
[05/12/2025, 13:46:01] Andie: By delegating the job of holding ideas to a "Second Brain," you build trust with your own subconscious. Your brain learns that it's safe to let go of an idea because it knows exactly where to find it later.
[05/12/2025, 13:46:28] Andie: Tiago teaches this because he knows that in our modern world, we are flooded with information. True creativity doesn't come from having a good memory; it comes from making connections between the things you've captured.

To do that, your brain needs to be free to do what it does best: think, dream, and create. It cannot do that if it's being used as a glorified to-do list, constantly reminding you of all the "dopamine tabs" you have open.
[05/12/2025, 13:47:12] Andie: idk likkle e.g. *How You Would Use It (The Practical Steps)*

*The "Yasss" Moment:* You're on Instagram. You see a look. You get the "10 dopamine tokens."

*The Hijack (Capture):* Instead of letting it become an "open tab," you immediately hit the "Share" button and send it to a specific note in your notes app called "Fashion Inspiration" or a specific Pinterest board. You might add a quick tag like #datenight or #gottamakeit.

*The Release (Closing the Tab):* Because you have captured it in a system you trust, your brain can now let it go. The tab is closed. The RAM is cleared. The overwhelm disappears.

*The Creation (Retrieval):* Weeks later, when you're actually planning an outfit or have time to create, you open your "Second Brain." All your inspiration is there, organized and waiting for you. You can now act on it with clarity and focus.
[05/12/2025, 13:47:38] Andie: unless this is unproven to work?? what u think?

‚Äé[05/12/2025, 18:53:56] Andie: ‚Äéimage omitted
[05/12/2025, 18:55:31] Andie: which can cause anemia, so my red blood cells are denser than normal. This indicates Hemolysis (breakdown of red blood cells). Meaning my body is destroying red blood cells faster than normal because of their shape/variant.

[05/12/2025, 18:56:14] Andie: Ive had recurring, severe Folate deficiency
[05/12/2025, 18:56:53] Andie: Folate is required for the synthesis of dopamine, serotonin, and norepinephrine. Severe brain fog, "executive dysfunction," fatigue, and the feeling of "decline." I am running a high-performance engine (high cell turnover due to Hb C) with an empty fuel tank (Low Folate/Vit D).

[22/12/2025, 17:31:38] Andie: The Atlantic Fellows for Social and Economic Equity is a lifelong fellowship programme, meaning that both Residential and Non-Residential Fellows become Senior Fellows upon successful completion of their active fellowship year.

As Senior Fellows, they will be members of a global community that is committed to fighting inequalities and collaborating with each other. They will also receive coaching support, and access to a range of collaboration, learning, and funding opportunities.

AFSEE Senior Fellows also become part of a wider global community of Atlantic Fellows drawn from the seven Atlantic Fellows programmes, all working to challenge inequality in their regions and contexts.

[29/12/2025, 14:47:10] Andie: Events don‚Äôt happen as isolated points. [30/12/2025, 01:26:56] Andie: The Seed Determines the Tree
[30/12/2025, 01:27:21] Andie: If the foundational logic (the seed) is X, the outcome (the tree) has to be a larger version of X. The pattern has to repeat because the root code hasn't changed.
[30/12/2025, 01:27:47] Andie: The universe is lazy. Once it finds a pattern that works (or a power structure that works), it just copies and pastes it at a larger scale. That‚Äôs why your childhood trauma looks exactly like your adult relationship problems; it‚Äôs the same software running on a bigger computer.
[30/12/2025, 01:28:01] Andie: Because the present is just the past compounding. The pattern repeats because the underlying structure remains the same, even if the surface changes.
[30/12/2025, 01:28:25] Andie: If you don‚Äôt change the source code (the intent/the system), the output is mathematically inevitable.
